elements.content: Upon reacting P4S3 with AgAl(hfip)4 and AgAl(pftb)4 [hfip = OC(H)(CF3)2; pftb = OC(CF3)3], the compounds Ag(P4S3)Al(hfip)4 1 and Ag(P4S3)2 +[Al(pftb)4]- 2 formed in CS2 (1) or CS2/CH2Cl2 (2) solution. Compounds 1 and 2 were characterized by single-crystal X-ray structure determinations, Raman and solution NMR spectroscopy, and elemental analyses. One-dimensional chains of [Ag(P4S3) x ]∞ (x = 1, 1; x = 2, 2) formed in the solid state with P4S3 ligands that bridge through a 1,3-P,S, a 2,4-P,S, or a 3,4-P,P η1 coordination to the silver ions. Compound 2 with the least basic anion contains the first homoleptic metal(P4S3) complex. Compounds 1 and 2 also include the long sought sulfur coordination of P4S3. Raman spectra of 1 and 2 were assigned on the basis of DFT calculations of related species. The influence of the silver coordination on the geometry of the P4S3 cage is discussed, additionally aided by DFT calculations. Consequences for the frequently observed degradation of the cage are suggested. An experimental silver ion affinity scale based on the solid-state structures of several weak Lewis acid base adducts of type (L)AgAl(hfip)4 is given. The affinity of the ligand L to the silver ion increases according to P4 < CH2Cl2 < P4S3 < S8 < 1,2-C2H4Cl2 < toluene.
elements.clean_text: Upon reacting P4S3 with AgAl(hfip)4 and AgAl(pftb)4 [hfip = OC(H)(CF3)2; pftb = OC(CF3)3], the compounds Ag(P4S3)Al(hfip)4 1 and Ag(P4S3)2 +[Al(pftb)4]- 2 formed in CS2 (1) or CS2/CH2Cl2 (2) solution. Compounds 1 and 2 were characterized by single-crystal X-ray structure determinations, Raman and solution NMR spectroscopy, and elemental analyses. One-dimensional chains of [Ag(P4S3) x ]∞ (x = 1, 1; x = 2, 2) formed in the solid state with P4S3 ligands that bridge through a 1,3-P,S, a 2,4-P,S, or a 3,4-P,P η1 coordination to the silver ions. Compound 2 with the least basic anion contains the first homoleptic metal(P4S3) complex. Compounds 1 and 2 also include the long sought sulfur coordination of P4S3. Raman spectra of 1 and 2 were assigned on the basis of DFT calculations of related species. The influence of the silver coordination on the geometry of the P4S3 cage is discussed, additionally aided by DFT calculations. Consequences for the frequently observed degradation of the cage are suggested. An experimental silver ion affinity scale based on the solid-state structures of several weak Lewis acid base adducts of type (L)AgAl(hfip)4 is given. The affinity of the ligand L to the silver ion increases according to P4 < CH2Cl2 < P4S3 < S8 < 1,2-C2H4Cl2 < toluene.

elements.content: Recently, there has been a renewed interest in the coordination chemistry of small inorganic cage or ring molecules such as P4S3. However, the structural knowledge on intact coordinated P4S3 cages is limited to the apical η1-bound Ni(np3) and Mo(CO)5  4 complexes. Very recently, the X-ray powder structures of two apical η1-bound BX3 (X = Br, I) complexes of P4S3 were published. No further structurally characterized examples exist to the best of our knowledge. Normally, the P4S3 molecule degrades upon coordination to transition metal fragments, and phosphide and/or sulfide groups are incorporated into the complex. More recently, copper halide matrixes were shown to weakly coordinate intact phosphorus, phosphorus−selenium, and chalcogen cages, rings, and chains. We obtained undistorted homoleptic P4 and S8 complexes with the even weaker Lewis acid Ag+ 10 and the help of the very weakly coordinating anion (WCA) Al(pftb)4 - [pftb = OC(CF3)3], that is, Ag(η2-P4)2 + 12 and Ag(η4-S8)2 +. In this work, our primary intent was to investigate the coordination behavior of undistorted P4S3 molecules with the naked Ag+ ion. These weak complexes may be viewed as the primary steps of the usual degradation reactions of P4S3, and we were interested to learn about the most reactive coordination sites of this molecule with the simple Ag+ ion as a nonsterically hindered model for a transition metal fragment (cf. Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, there has been a renewed interest in the coordination chemistry of small inorganic cage or ring molecules such as P4S3. However, the structural knowledge on intact coordinated P4S3 cages is limited to the apical η1-bound Ni(np3) and Mo(CO)5 4 complexes. Very recently, the X-ray powder structures of two apical η1-bound BX3 (X = Br, I) complexes of P4S3 were published. No further structurally characterized examples exist to the best of our knowledge. Normally, the P4S3 molecule degrades upon coordination to transition metal fragments, and phosphide and/or sulfide groups are incorporated into the complex. More recently, copper halide matrixes were shown to weakly coordinate intact phosphorus, phosphorus-selenium, and chalcogen cages, rings, and chains. We obtained undistorted homoleptic P4 and S8 complexes with the even weaker Lewis acid Ag+10 and the help of the very weakly coordinating anion (WCA) Al(pftb)4 - [pftb = OC(CF3)3], that is, Ag(η2-P4)2 +12 and Ag(η4-S8)2 +. In this work, our primary intent was to investigate the coordination behavior of undistorted P4S3 molecules with the naked Ag+ ion. These weak complexes may be viewed as the primary steps of the usual degradation reactions of P4S3, and we were interested to learn about the most reactive coordination sites of this molecule with the simple Ag+ ion as a nonsterically hindered model for a transition metal fragment (cf. Figure ).

elements.content: Possible coordination sites of theC 3 v symmetric P4S3 molecule.
elements.clean_text: 1  Possible coordination sites of theC 3  v  symmetric P4S3 molecule.

elements.content: In contrast to the reactions of AgAl(hfip)4 [hfip = OC(H)(CF3)2] and AgAl(pftb)4  11 with P4  12 or S8, 13 no isolated ions or molecules but in the solid-state polymeric silver-P4S3 complexes (P4S3)AgAl(hfip)4 1 and [Ag(P4S3)2 +][Al(pftb)4 -] 2 formed from CS2 (1) and CS2/CH2Cl2 (10:1, 2) solution (eqs 1 and 2). Compounds 1 and 2 are highly soluble in CH2Cl2 and CS2/CH2Cl2 mixtures, and therefore it is likely that dissolved 1 adopts an isolated molecular structure as in (L)AgAl(hfip)4 and dissolved 2 adopts a structure with discrete isolated ions as in Ag(L)2 +[Al(pftb)4]- (L = P4[12b]; S8  13). The variable temperature (VT) 31P NMR spectra of 1 and 2 in CD2Cl2 are nearly unchanged if compared to P4S3 in the same solvent (Δδ = 2−10 ppm) and indicate exchange reactions and a weak bonding to the silver ion. However, the ready observation of a 31P solution NMR spectrum at −90 °C showed that the signals are due to 1 and 2 and not to free P4S3 which is insoluble in CH2Cl2 at −90 °C. Similar to 1 and 2, the position of the 31P NMR shift of the related silver-P4 adducts was only very slightly changed if compared to free P4  16 and in solid P4S3*BX3 Δ(δ31P) was 5−57 ppm. Also the 2 J PP coupling constants in 1 and 2 are only slightly changed by Δ(2 J PP) = 1−6 Hz if compared to free P4S3 in the same solvent (69 Hz). Compounds 1 and 2 are stable for at least several hours in daylight but highly sensitive toward oxygen, and crystals exposed to the atmosphere turn brownish-black within less than a second. The solid-state structures of 1 and 2 contain one-dimensional infinite chains that are built from tetracoordinate Ag+ ions and one or two bridging P4S3 molecules. In 1, the P4S3 molecules adopt two independent positions with a 68.6 (=1a) and 31.4% (=1b) occupation each. All η1 bonding modes shown in Figure are realized in 1 and 2, but no η2-P,S or η2-P,P coordination as in the Ag(η2-P4) complexes12 was observed. In 1 (Figure ) with the more basic anion two of the four silver coordination sites are occupied by the oxygen atoms of the Al(hfip)4 - anion at 2.435(4) and 2.455(4) Å as in (molecular) (L)AgAl(hfip)4 d(Ag−O) = 2.345(3)−2.737(3) Å (L = P4 12b; S8 13). In contrast, 2 (Figure ) with the less basic anion11 has no silver-anion contacts below 4.0 Å, and to complete the coordination environment the silver ion coordinates a second P4S3 molecule as in (monomeric) Ag(L)2 +[Al(pftb)4 -] (L = P4  12b; S8  13). (Full ellipsoid plots of 1 and 2 with distances and angles are deposited.)
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

In contrast to the reactions of AgAl(hfip)4 [hfip = OC(H)(CF3)2] and AgAl(pftb)4             11 with P4             12 or S8,13 no isolated ions or molecules but in the solid-state polymeric silver-P4S3  complexes (P4S3)AgAl(hfip)4 1  and [Ag(P4S3)2 +][Al(pftb)4 -] 2  formed from CS2 (1) and CS2/CH2Cl2 (10:1, 2) solution (eqs 1 and 2).        Compounds 1 and 2 are highly soluble in CH2Cl2 and CS2/CH2Cl2 mixtures, and therefore it is likely that dissolved 1 adopts an isolated molecular structure as in (L)AgAl(hfip)4 and dissolved 2 adopts a structure with discrete isolated ions as in Ag(L)2 +[Al(pftb)4]- (L = P4[12b]; S8 13). The variable temperature (VT) 31P NMR spectra of 1 and 2 in CD2Cl2 are nearly unchanged if compared to P4S3 in the same solvent (Δδ = 2-10 ppm) and indicate exchange reactions and a weak bonding to the silver ion. However, the ready observation of a 31P solution NMR spectrum at -90 °C showed that the signals are due to 1 and 2 and not to free P4S3 which is insoluble in CH2Cl2 at -90 °C. Similar to 1 and 2, the position of the 31P NMR shift of the related silver-P4 adducts was only very slightly changed if compared to free P4 16 and in solid P4S3*BX3 Δ(δ31P) was 5-57 ppm. Also the 2 J PP coupling constants in 1 and 2 are only slightly changed by Δ(2 J PP) = 1-6 Hz if compared to free P4S3 in the same solvent (69 Hz). Compounds 1 and 2 are stable for at least several hours in daylight but highly sensitive toward oxygen, and crystals exposed to the atmosphere turn brownish-black within less than a second. The solid-state structures of 1 and 2 contain one-dimensional infinite chains that are built from tetracoordinate Ag+ ions and one or two bridging P4S3 molecules. In 1, the P4S3 molecules adopt two independent positions with a 68.6 (=1a) and 31.4% (=1b) occupation each. All η1 bonding modes shown in Figure  are realized in 1 and 2, but no η2-P,S or η2-P,P coordination as in the Ag(η2-P4) complexes12 was observed. In 1 (Figure ) with the more basic anion two of the four silver coordination sites are occupied by the oxygen atoms of the Al(hfip)4 - anion at 2.435(4) and 2.455(4) Å as in (molecular) (L)AgAl(hfip)4 d(Ag-O) = 2.345(3)-2.737(3) Å (L = P4 12b; S8 13). In contrast, 2 (Figure ) with the less basic anion11 has no silver-anion contacts below 4.0 Å, and to complete the coordination environment the silver ion coordinates a second P4S3 molecule as in (monomeric)  Ag(L)2 +[Al(pftb)4 -] (L = P4 12b; S8 13). (Full ellipsoid plots of 1 and 2 with distances and angles are deposited.)

elements.content: The solid-state structure of the polymeric Ag(P4S3) moiety in 1 at 170 K. (a) This denotes the structure occupied by 68.6% of the P4S3 molecules in 1a, (b) and that occupied by 31.4% in 1b. The C(H)(CF3)2 ligands of the Al(hfip)4 - anion were omitted for clarity. The bonds within the AlO4 unit and the P4S3 cage were drawn in black, those to the silver ion in gray. The Ag atoms completing the coordination on the left and right are also shown. Thermal ellipsoids were drawn at the 25% probability level, P atoms are shown in black, S atoms in light gray, Ag atoms in medium gray, and Al, O in white.
elements.clean_text: 2  The solid-state structure of the polymeric Ag(P4S3) moiety in 1 at 170 K. (a) This denotes the structure occupied by 68.6% of the P4S3 molecules in 1a, (b) and that occupied by 31.4% in 1b. The C(H)(CF3)2 ligands of the Al(hfip)4 - anion were omitted for clarity. The bonds within the AlO4 unit and the P4S3 cage were drawn in black, those to the silver ion in gray. The Ag atoms completing the coordination on the left and right are also shown. Thermal ellipsoids were drawn at the 25% probability level, P atoms are shown in black, S atoms in light gray, Ag atoms in medium gray, and Al, O in white.

elements.content: The solid-state structure of the polymeric homoleptic Ag(P4S3)2 + cation in 2 at 150 K. One complete repetitive [Ag(P4S3)2]2 unit of the infinite chain of [Ag(P4S3)2]∞ containing six-membered planar Ag2P4 and eight-membered slightly puckered Ag2P4S2 rings is shown. The bonds within the P4S3 cage were drawn in black, those to the silver ion in gray. The P and S atoms completing the coordination of the left and right Ag atoms are also shown. Thermal ellipsoids were drawn at the 25% probability level, P atoms are shown in black, S atoms in light gray, and Ag atoms in medium gray. The Al(pftb)4 - anion was omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  The solid-state structure of the polymeric homoleptic Ag(P4S3)2 + cation in 2 at 150 K. One complete repetitive [Ag(P4S3)2]2 unit of the infinite chain of [Ag(P4S3)2]∞ containing six-membered planar Ag2P4 and eight-membered slightly puckered Ag2P4S2 rings is shown. The bonds within the P4S3 cage were drawn in black, those to the silver ion in gray. The P and S atoms completing the coordination of the left and right Ag atoms are also shown. Thermal ellipsoids were drawn at the 25% probability level, P atoms are shown in black, S atoms in light gray, and Ag atoms in medium gray. The Al(pftb)4 - anion was omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
Comparison of the Structural Parameter of Free and Coordinated P4S3 Molecules

parameter P4S3  24 1a 18 2 (np3)Ni(P4S3)3 d(Ag−P)range 2.523(4) 2.512(1)−2.540(1) d(Ag−P)av 2.529 d(Ag−S) 2.571(2) 2.657(1) d(P−P)range 2.223(1)−2.235(1) 2.197(5)−2.295(5) 2.217(1)−2.256(1) a d(P−P)av 2.227 2.257 2.237 2.223(7) d(Papical−S)range 2.089(1)−2.098(1) 2.139(4)−2.189(4) 2.094(1)−2.134(1) a d(Papical−S)av 2.092 2.158 2.112 2.129(4) d(Pbasal−S)range 2.087(1)−2.089(1) 1.959(4)−2.146(4) 2.069(1)−2.110(1) a d(Pbasal−S)av 2.086 2.071 2.083 2.090(5)

a  Three-fold symmetry in the crystal, therefore no range.

The P4S3 molecules bridge to the Ag+ ions through a 1,3-P,P (1b), a 2,4-P,S (1a, 2), or a 3,4-P,P (2) coordination (labeling as in Figure ). Planar six- and slightly puckered eight-membered rings formed in 2 (Figure ). Similar planar M2P4 rings were earlier found by Scheer et al. (M = Mo) and Scherer et al. (M = Re). The 1,3 or 2,4 coordination in 1 and 2 is similar to the 1,3 coordination of the S8 molecule in (S8)2AgAsF6  21 or polymeric (S8)Rh2(O2CCF3)4. The Ag−P distance in 1a 18 is 2.523(4) Å; in 2 they are 2.540(1), 2.534(1) (six-ring), and 2.512(1) Å (eight-ring) − similar to the Ag−P distances in the Ag(η2-P4) adducts of 2.512−2.548 Å. Ag−S bond lengths range from 2.571(2) in 1a to 2.657(1) in 2 (eight-ring) and are comparable to those of the Ag(S8) adducts as in (S8)2AgAsF6  21 (2.724 and 2.802 Å) or [Ag(S8)2 +][Al(pftb)4 -] (2.622, 2.794, 2.838 Å). Surprisingly, both Ag−P and Ag−S distances are similar to the values found in the solid binaries Ag2S and Ag3P11 containing the charged and, therefore, seemingly more basic S2- and P11 3- anions. However, similar observations were made frequently for the distances of Ag+/Cu+ to neighboring neutral or anionic arrangements. The structural parameters of the coordinated P4S3 molecules in 1 are more affected by the coordination than those observed in 2; that is, P−P [P−S] bonds in 1a 18 range from 2.197(5) to 2.295(5) [1.959(4) to 2.189(4)] Å and in 2 from 2.217(1) to 2.256(1) [2.071(1) to 2.134(1)] Å. The average distances in 1 and 2 compare well to those observed in free P4S3  24 and coordinated (np3)Ni(P4S3)3 (see Table ).

The 1,3 or 2,4 coordination in 1 and 2 is similar to the 1,3 coordination of the S8 molecule in (S8)2AgAsF6 21 or polymeric (S8)Rh2(O2CCF3)4. Ag-S bond lengths range from 2.571(2) in 1a to 2.657(1) in 2 (eight-ring) and are comparable to those of the Ag(S8) adducts as in (S8)2AgAsF6 21 (2.724 and 2.802 Å) or [Ag(S8)2 +][Al(pftb)4 -] (2.622, 2.794, 2.838 Å). Surprisingly, both Ag-P and Ag-S distances are similar to the values found in the solid binaries Ag2S and Ag3P11 containing the charged and, therefore, seemingly more basic S2- and P11 3- anions. However, similar observations were made frequently for the distances of Ag+/Cu+ to neighboring neutral or anionic arrangements. The structural parameters of the coordinated P4S3 molecules in 1 are more affected by the coordination than those observed in 2; that is, P-P [P-S] bonds in 1a 18 range from 2.197(5) to 2.295(5) [1.959(4) to 2.189(4)] Å and in 2 from 2.217(1) to 2.256(1) [2.071(1) to 2.134(1)] Å. elements.content: As seen from Table , P−S or P−P bonds in 1 and 2 are shortened or elongated by up to +0.10/−0.13 Å if compared to free P4S3. The shortest P−S bond length of 1.959(4) Å in 1a is close to a PS double bond; that is, d(PSexo) in P4S10 is 1.91 Å. This short P−S bond is accompanied by an adjacent very long P−S bond of 2.189(4) Å. Figure gives selected possible VB structures that may be responsible for this phenomenon.
elements.clean_text: As seen from Table , P-S or P-P bonds in 1 and 2 are shortened or elongated by up to +0.10/-0.13 Å if compared to free P4S3. The shortest P-S bond length of 1.959(4) Å in 1a  is close to a PS double bond; that is, d(PSexo) in P4S10 is 1.91 Å. This short P-S bond is accompanied by an adjacent very long P-S bond of 2.189(4) Å. Figure  gives selected possible VB structures that may be responsible for this phenomenon.

elements.content: Selected VB structures that possibly account for the short and/or long adjacent P−S distances in1a. Other possible VB structures are presumably of less weight and were therefore omitted.
elements.clean_text: 4  Selected VB structures that possibly account for the short and/or long adjacent P-S distances in1a. Other possible VB structures are presumably of less weight and were therefore omitted.

elements.content: In agreement with the DFT calculations below, VB structures A and C possibly account for the short P−S bond and C for the long adjacent P−S distance. Other possible VB structures (not shown) appear to be of less weight.
elements.clean_text: In agreement with the DFT calculations below, VB structures A and C possibly account for the short P-S bond and C for the long adjacent P-S distance. Other possible VB structures (not shown) appear to be of less weight.

elements.content: To understand the bonding within the Ag(P4S3) adducts, to verify the two geometries found in 1ab, to compare the six- and eight-ring in 2, as well as to calculate the vibrational frequencies of these species to aid the assignment of the experimental Raman frequencies of 1 and 2, we fully optimized P4S3 (C 3 v ), two isomers of Ag2P4S3 2+ (C1) as included in 1ab, and the six- (C 2 h ) and eight-ring (C i ) (AgP4S3)2 2+ as found as part of 2 at the (RI-)BP86/SVP (DFT-)level. All optimized geometries shown in Figure are in good qualitative agreement with the experimental structures and are true minima with no imaginary frequencies. All bond lengths are overestimated by about 0.05−0.10 Å as frequently found with DFT.
elements.clean_text: To understand the bonding within the Ag(P4S3) adducts, to verify the two geometries found in 1ab, to compare the six- and eight-ring in 2, as well as to calculate the vibrational frequencies of these species to aid the assignment of the experimental Raman frequencies of 1 and 2, we fully optimized P4S3 (C 3  v ), two isomers of Ag2P4S3 2+ (C1) as included in 1ab, and the six- (C 2  h ) and eight-ring (C  i ) (AgP4S3)2 2+ as found as part of 2 at the (RI-)BP86/SVP (DFT-)level. All optimized geometries shown in Figure  are in good qualitative agreement with the experimental structures and are true minima with no  imaginary frequencies. All bond lengths are overestimated by about 0.05-0.10 Å as frequently found with DFT.

elements.content: BP86/SVP optimized structures, total and relative energies of P4S3, as well as two isomers of Ag2P4S3 2+ and (AgP4S3)2 2+ as observed as parts of the polymeric solid-state structures of 1 and 2. Distances are given in Å and bond angles in deg. Computed partial charges are given in italics and shared electron numbers in italics and underlined.
elements.clean_text: 5  BP86/SVP optimized structures, total and relative energies of P4S3, as well as two isomers of Ag2P4S3 2+ and (AgP4S3)2 2+ as observed as parts of the polymeric solid-state structures of 1 and 2. Distances are given in Å and bond angles in deg. Computed partial charges are given in italics and shared electron numbers in italics and underlined.

elements.content: A large range of the P−S bond lengths similar to that in the experiment was found in the calculation, and the shared electron numbers (SENs) of the P−S bonds range from 0.83 to 1.16 but only 1.01 to 1.09 in free P4S3. This supports the importance of the proposed VB structures A and C in Figure above. Both sets of isomers in Figure are almost isoenergetic, and their relative energies differ only by 6.77 kJ mol-1 (Ag2P4S3 2+) or 3.12 kJ mol-1 [(AgP4S3)2 2+]. With these small energetic differences, it is easy to understand that two different coordination modes are found in the solid-state structures of 1 and 2. From the calculated partial charges and SENs it is evident that (i) the Ag−P and Ag−S interactions have covalent contributions and therefore SENs ranging from 0.34 to 0.81 and (ii) the positive charges are delocalized over the entire species with higher partial charges residing on Ag (+0.31 to +0.54) and P (+0.07 to +0.33), but the sulfur atoms are almost uncharged (−0.02 to +0.08). If the Ag−P4S3 bonding would be purely electrostatic, one would expect a preference for the formation of Ag−S bonds since the sulfur atoms in free P4S3 are negatively polarized (−0.09, Figure ), and, on electrostatic grounds, bonds to sulfur should be favored.
elements.clean_text: A large range of the P-S bond lengths similar to that in the experiment was found in the calculation, and the shared electron numbers (SENs) of the P-S bonds range from 0.83 to 1.16 but only 1.01 to 1.09 in free P4S3. This supports the importance of the proposed VB structures A and C in Figure  above. Both sets of isomers in Figure  are almost isoenergetic, and their relative energies differ only by 6.77 kJ mol-1 (Ag2P4S3 2+) or 3.12 kJ mol-1 [(AgP4S3)2 2+]. With these small energetic differences, it is easy to understand that two different coordination modes are found in the solid-state structures of 1 and 2. From the calculated partial charges and SENs it is evident that (i) the Ag-P and Ag-S interactions have covalent contributions and therefore SENs ranging from 0.34 to 0.81 and (ii) the positive charges are delocalized over the entire species with higher partial charges residing on Ag (+0.31 to +0.54) and P (+0.07 to +0.33), but the sulfur atoms are almost uncharged (-0.02 to +0.08). If the Ag-P4S3 bonding would be purely electrostatic, one would expect a preference for the formation of Ag-S bonds since the sulfur atoms in free P4S3 are negatively polarized (-0.09, Figure ), and, on electrostatic grounds, bonds to sulfur should be favored.

elements.content: The Raman spectra of 1 and 2, shown in Figure , and free P4S3 are compared in Table . Bands of the anions and the coordinated P4S3 molecules are visible in Figure . Because of the lowering of the symmetry upon silver coordination, several degenerate or Raman forbidden modes split in C 3 v -P4S3 and are visible in 1 and 2. The frequencies of the anions are listed in a deposited section. Assignments were made on the basis of those reported for the free P4S3 molecule and the calculated BP86/SVP frequencies of Ag2P4S3 2+ and (AgP4S3)2 2+.

The frequencies of the anions are listed in a deposited section. Assignments were made on the basis of those reported for the free P4S3 molecule and the calculated BP86/SVP frequencies of Ag2P4S3 2+ and (AgP4S3)2 2+.

elements.content: FT-Raman spectra of1 (bottom trace) and 2 (top trace) between 100 and 900 cm-1.

Experimental Room Temperature Raman Spectra of P4S3, 1, and 2 on Our Spectrometer (1064 nm Radiation, 2 cm-1 Resolution) [in cm-1] a

The vibrational frequencies of the coordinated P4S3 molecules in 1 and 2 versus those of free P4S3 are changed by a maximum of about 30 cm-1. By comparison to the calculated frequencies of the Ag2P4S3 2+ and (AgP4S3)2 2+ isomers in Table , it is evident that each of the two different isomers included in the solid-state structures of 1 and 2 gives a distinct Raman spectrum that is separated from each other (Table ). The highest energy bands ν(Papical−S3) (E) of the coordinated P4S3 molecules are found 20 cm-1 higher in energy than those in free P4S3. This is in agreement with the solid-state structures of 1 and 2, where at least one apical P−S bond is shorter, and therefore stronger, by 0.12725 (1a) to 0.018 (2) Å, as in free P4S3.
elements.clean_text: The vibrational frequencies of the coordinated P4S3 molecules in 1 and 2 versus those of free P4S3 are changed by a maximum  of about 30 cm-1. By comparison to the calculated frequencies of the Ag2P4S3 2+ and (AgP4S3)2 2+ isomers in Table , it is evident that each of the two different isomers included in the solid-state structures of 1 and 2 gives a distinct Raman spectrum that is separated from each other (Table ). The highest energy bands ν(Papical-S3) (E) of the coordinated P4S3 molecules are found 20 cm-1 higher in energy than those in free P4S3. This is in agreement with the solid-state structures of 1 and 2, where at least one apical P-S bond is shorter, and therefore stronger, by 0.12725 (1a) to 0.018 (2) Å, as in free P4S3.

elements.content: An Experimental Silver Ion Affinity Scale. Silver ion affinity (SIA) scales were previously established in the gas phase by mass spectrometry and computational chemistry. However, to the best of our knowledge, no attempt has been made to obtain a SIA scale based on solid-state structures. Recently, we structurally characterized several Lewis acid base adducts (L)AgAl(hfip)4 and (L)AgAl(hftb)4 [hftb = OC(CH3)(CF3)2], that is, L = toluene, CH2Cl2, 1,2-Cl2C2H4, S8, P4, and P4S3. A common structural feature of these complexes is that the silver ion is coordinated by two oxygen atoms of the anion as schematically shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text: An Experimental Silver Ion Affinity Scale. Silver ion affinity (SIA) scales were previously established in the gas phase by mass spectrometry and computational chemistry. However, to the best of our knowledge, no attempt has been made to obtain a SIA scale based on solid-state structures. Recently, we structurally characterized several Lewis acid base adducts (L)AgAl(hfip)4 and (L)AgAl(hftb)4 [hftb = OC(CH3)(CF3)2], that is, L = toluene, CH2Cl2, 1,2-Cl2C2H4, S8, P4, and P4S3. A common structural feature of these complexes is that the silver ion is coordinated by two oxygen atoms of the anion as schematically shown in Figure .

elements.clean_text: 7  Silver coordination in the Lewis acid base adducts (L) x AgAl(OR)4; R = C(H)(CF3)2 or C(CH3)(CF3)2.

elements.content: Clearly the strengths of the Ag−O coordination to the anion are a measure for the strengths of the interaction to the coordinated Lewis base L. The shorter is the Ag−O distance, the lower is the SIA to the Lewis base which leaves the silver ion more electrophilic. Long Ag−O separations are an indication for a strong SIA to the ligand L. A measure for the strength of the Ag−O interaction is the average Ag−O distance; however, less ambiguous36 is the sum of the Ag−O bond valences s calculated according to I. D. Brown's bond valence method. All structural data and bond valences s are collected in Table .
elements.clean_text: Clearly the strengths of the Ag-O coordination to the anion are a measure for the strengths of the interaction to the coordinated Lewis base L. The shorter is the Ag-O distance, the lower is the SIA to the Lewis base which leaves the silver ion more electrophilic. Long Ag-O separations are an indication for a strong SIA to the ligand L. A measure for the strength of the Ag-O interaction is the average Ag-O distance; however, less ambiguous36 is the sum of the Ag-O bond valences s calculated according to I. D. Brown's bond valence method. All structural data and bond valences s are collected in Table .

elements.content: A comparison of the similar structural parameters of the Ag−P4 complexes of the Al(hfip)4 - and Al(hftb)4 - anions in Table shows that both have virtually the same basicity, and therefore both can be used to establish a solid-state SIA scale. On the basis of the strengths s of the Ag−O contacts in Table , the affinity of the ligand L to the silver ion increases according to P4 < CH2Cl2 < P4S3 < S8 < 1,2-C2H4Cl2 < toluene. This leveling is in good agreement with our observation that the Ag−P4 complexes were only accessible in pentane or CS2 solution12b but not from CH2Cl2. In contrast, the Ag(S8) complexes were also prepared from CHCl3 or CH2Cl2.
elements.clean_text: A comparison of the similar structural parameters of the Ag-P4 complexes of the Al(hfip)4 - and Al(hftb)4 - anions in Table  shows that both have virtually the same basicity, and therefore both can be used to establish a solid-state SIA scale. On the basis of the strengths s of the Ag-O contacts in Table , the affinity of the ligand L to the silver ion increases according to P4 < CH2Cl2 < P4S3 < S8 < 1,2-C2H4Cl2 < toluene. This leveling is in good agreement with our observation that the Ag-P4 complexes were only accessible in pentane or CS2 solution12b but not from CH2Cl2. In contrast, the Ag(S8) complexes were also prepared from CHCl3 or CH2Cl2.

elements.content: The Ag−P4S3 complexes in 1 and 2 are the first polymeric Lewis acid base adducts of AgAl(OR)4 which prior always led to isolated molecular (OR = hfip) or isolated salt structures (OR = pftb). Currently, we examine the possible one-dimensional electric and silver ion conductivity of 1 and 2 (cf. copper halide adducts in refs , ). The coordination chemistry of ternary mixtures AgAl(OR)4/P4S3/L is an interesting perspective with a possible extension to supramolecular chemistry. These ternary mixtures should lead to larger but isolated purely inorganic supramolecular arrays which include six- or eight-membered rings as in 2 (Figure ) as building blocks and in which the free coordination sites of the silver ion are saturated by the third ligand L, that is, S8 or P4. Synthetic efforts in this direction are on the way.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The Ag-P4S3 complexes in 1 and 2 are the first polymeric Lewis acid base adducts of AgAl(OR)4 which prior always led to isolated molecular (OR = hfip) or isolated salt structures (OR = pftb). Currently, we examine the possible one-dimensional electric and silver ion conductivity of 1 and 2 (cf. copper halide adducts in refs , ). The coordination chemistry of ternary mixtures AgAl(OR)4/P4S3/L is an interesting perspective with a possible extension to supramolecular chemistry. These ternary mixtures should lead to larger but isolated purely inorganic supramolecular arrays which include six- or eight-membered rings as in 2 (Figure ) as building blocks and in which the free coordination sites of the silver ion are saturated by the third ligand L, that is, S8 or P4. Synthetic efforts in this direction are on the way.

elements.content: The exclusive but flexible η1 coordination of all P4S3 cage atoms shows that the electronic structure of P4S3 is different to that of tetrahedro-P4; P4 includes no sterically active lone pair orbitals as shown by the η2 coordination to the silver ion of the Al(OR)4 - anions. In contrast, P4S3 has sterically active lone pair orbitals on all atoms. Although incorporating a cyclo P3 unit similar to P4, molecular P4S3 prefers η1 coordination. Moreover, 1 and 2 include the first example of the long sought2b sulfur coordination which had been postulated but was not structurally verified. This flexible S or P coordination is the starting point for the frequently observed further degradation of the P4S3 molecule. Presumably, η1 P4S3 rearranges intermediately to a η2 complex, and then the transition metal fragments insert into the P−P (as in {IrCl(CO)(P4S3)(PPh3)}2  40) or P−S bond as in [cp4Cr4(CO)9(P4S3)]7a (with further rearrangement). The observed redistribution7a of the P and S atoms of P4S3 upon reaction with transition metal fragments may be due to the facile exchange of a P−S single bond for a PS double bond as in the bond-no-bond-structure C in Figure above. On the basis of the strengths s of the Ag−O contacts of several (L)AgAl(OR)4 complexes, the affinity of the ligand L to the silver ion increases according to P4 < CH2Cl2 < P4S3 < S8 < 1,2-C2H4Cl2 < toluene.
elements.clean_text: The exclusive but flexible η1 coordination of all P4S3 cage atoms shows that the electronic structure of P4S3 is different to that of tetrahedro-P4; P4 includes no sterically active lone pair orbitals as shown by the η2 coordination to the silver ion of the Al(OR)4 - anions. In contrast, P4S3 has sterically active lone pair orbitals on all atoms. Although incorporating a cyclo P3 unit similar to P4, molecular P4S3 prefers η1 coordination. Moreover, 1 and 2 include the first example of the long sought2b sulfur coordination which had been postulated but was not structurally verified. This flexible S or P coordination is the starting point for the frequently observed further degradation of the P4S3 molecule. Presumably, η1 P4S3 rearranges intermediately to a η2 complex, and then the transition metal fragments insert into the P-P (as in {IrCl(CO)(P4S3)(PPh3)}2 40) or P-S bond as in [cp4Cr4(CO)9(P4S3)]7a (with further rearrangement). The observed redistribution7a of the P and S atoms of P4S3 upon reaction with transition metal fragments may be due to the facile exchange of a P-S single bond for a PS double bond as in the bond-no-bond-structure C in Figure  above. On the basis of the strengths s of the Ag-O contacts of several (L)AgAl(OR)4 complexes, the affinity of the ligand L to the silver ion increases according to P4 < CH2Cl2 < P4S3 < S8 < 1,2-C2H4Cl2 < toluene.

elements.content: All manipulations were performed using standard Schlenk or drybox techniques in an atmosphere of purified dinitrogen or argon (H2O and O2 < 1 ppm). All solvents were rigorously dried by standard procedures, distilled, degassed prior to use, and stored under N2. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AC250 spectrometer and referenced against the solvent (1H, 13C) or external aqueous AlCl3 (27Al) and 85% H3PO4 (31P). Raman spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Bruker IFS 66v spectrometer equipped with the Raman module FRA106 in sealed NMR tubes or melting point capillaries (1064 nm radiation, 2 cm-1 resolution). Elemental analyses were performed by the analytical laboratory of the institute.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Details

All manipulations were performed using standard Schlenk or drybox techniques in an atmosphere of purified dinitrogen or argon (H2O and O2 < 1 ppm). All solvents were rigorously dried by standard procedures, distilled, degassed prior to use, and stored under N2. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AC250 spectrometer and referenced against the solvent (1H, 13C) or external aqueous AlCl3 (27Al) and 85% H3PO4 (31P). Raman spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Bruker IFS 66v spectrometer equipped with the Raman module FRA106 in sealed NMR tubes or melting point capillaries (1064 nm radiation, 2 cm-1 resolution). Elemental analyses were performed by the analytical laboratory of the institute.

elements.content: Full ellipsoid plots of 1 and 2 including the anions and individual structural parameters, drawings of the disorder in 1ab, X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format, and full tables of the experimental anion Raman bands as well as the calculated (AgP4S3)2 2+ vibrational modes (PDF). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text:

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content: The solid-state structure of the polymeric Ag(P4S3) moiety in 1 at 170 K. (a) This denotes the structure occupied by 68.6% of the P4S3 molecules in 1a, (b) and that occupied by 31.4% in 1b. The C(H)(CF3)2 ligands of the Al(hfip)4 - anion were omitted for clarity. The bonds within the AlO4 unit and the P4S3 cage were drawn in black, those to the silver ion in gray. The Ag atoms completing the coordination on the left and right are also shown. Thermal ellipsoids were drawn at the 25% probability level, P atoms are shown in black, S atoms in light gray, Ag atoms in medium gray, and Al, O in white.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  The solid-state structure of the polymeric Ag(P4S3) moiety in 1 at 170 K. (a) This denotes the structure occupied by 68.6% of the P4S3 molecules in 1a, (b) and that occupied by 31.4% in 1b. The C(H)(CF3)2 ligands of the Al(hfip)4 - anion were omitted for clarity. The bonds within the AlO4 unit and the P4S3 cage were drawn in black, those to the silver ion in gray. The Ag atoms completing the coordination on the left and right are also shown. Thermal ellipsoids were drawn at the 25% probability level, P atoms are shown in black, S atoms in light gray, Ag atoms in medium gray, and Al, O in white.

cln_elements.content: The solid-state structure of the polymeric homoleptic Ag(P4S3)2 + cation in 2 at 150 K. One complete repetitive [Ag(P4S3)2]2 unit of the infinite chain of [Ag(P4S3)2]∞ containing six-membered planar Ag2P4 and eight-membered slightly puckered Ag2P4S2 rings is shown. The bonds within the P4S3 cage were drawn in black, those to the silver ion in gray. The P and S atoms completing the coordination of the left and right Ag atoms are also shown. Thermal ellipsoids were drawn at the 25% probability level, P atoms are shown in black, S atoms in light gray, and Ag atoms in medium gray. The Al(pftb)4 - anion was omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  The solid-state structure of the polymeric homoleptic Ag(P4S3)2 + cation in 2 at 150 K. One complete repetitive [Ag(P4S3)2]2 unit of the infinite chain of [Ag(P4S3)2]∞ containing six-membered planar Ag2P4 and eight-membered slightly puckered Ag2P4S2 rings is shown. The bonds within the P4S3 cage were drawn in black, those to the silver ion in gray. The P and S atoms completing the coordination of the left and right Ag atoms are also shown. Thermal ellipsoids were drawn at the 25% probability level, P atoms are shown in black, S atoms in light gray, and Ag atoms in medium gray. The Al(pftb)4 - anion was omitted for clarity.

metadata.title:
Extending the Coordination Chemistry of Molecular P4S3:  The
Polymeric Ag(P4S3)+ and Ag(P4S3)2
+ Cations
